title: Getting to grips with platforms
body:
A platform is a major piece of software on which smaller pieces of software and content can be run. In open data, the largest platform is the web itself, which provides access to all data. However, a number of purpose-built softwares also exist to help simplify publishing open data and provide interactive tools for users to explore.

In this module we’ll look at:
  • Recognising open data platforms
  • Understanding their importance to users
  • Evaluating the key options
  • Using platforms to explore data

title: Open data platforms – in 2 minutes
body: The ODI’s David Tarrant explains what open data platforms are, the differnt types available and the advatages of them to users.

title: What is an open data platform?
displayTitle: What is an open data platform?
body:
Open data platforms are pieces of software that streamline the process of publishing and managing open data on the web.

For publishers, an open data platform provides a specific pathway for getting data on the web. Specific workflows guide publishers through the process of publishing proper open data.

For users, use of a limited number of platforms provides consistency and ease of access to open data from around the globe.

title: Key features of open data platforms
displayTitle: Key features of open data platforms
body: Open data platforms make open data discoverable and usable in a consistant way.
instruction: Click the forward arrow find out more.Select the ‘+’ sign to explore further, then swipe the image to see more.

_items.title: Discovery
_items.body:
Open data platforms have been built with the purpose of promoting available data for users. To this end they have been specifically designed to easy the discovery and reuse of open data.

Each platform is search optimised and provides data feeds that can be discovered and indexed in systems across the web.

enigma.io is a startup that is already indexing open data to make it easier to search.

Discover more at enigma.io

_items.title: Consistancy
_items.body:
There is currently a limited number of open data platforms, thus discovering huge amounts of open data does not require knowledge of countless technologies.

Additionally, each of the platforms has taken a considered approach to how they look to a user, making each one easy to instantly identify.

For example look at: data.gov.uk, data.gov.bf and data.gov.md. Also note that most governments are using the same pattern for the web address of their data.

_items.title: Access
_items.body:
The evolution of open standards on the web has also led to a consistent machine interfaces (APIs) for discovering, accessing and using data.

With a limited number of platforms all implementing similar interfaces, but with a different set of features, users are provided the maximum potential for easy access and reuse.

Additionally the platforms are all adopting similar structures and formats for exposing metadata as well as the data itself.

title: Approaches
body: Different platforms provide different approaches to publishing and exposing open data. Discover the different approaches below:

_items.title: Data catalogs
_items.body:
A open data catalog is a platform which lists datasets that exist on the web. Such platforms are like a library database; they know what open data exists, what it is about and where it is.

An open data catalog links out to data that is located somewhere else on the web. They provide a consistent way of searching across a diverse set of data that is widely scattered.

Often this catalogues are able to link directly to the data download, thus it is not always obvious that you are browsing a catlog.

The CKAN platform, as used by data.gov.uk is a good example of a data catalog.

_items.title: Data management
_items.body:
Even though data must be free to use, this does not mean that it must be free to access.

There is a cost in creating, maintaining and publishing useable data.

Ideally, any fee for data should be no more than the reasonable reproduction cost of the unit of data that is requested.

This reproduction cost tends to zero for many datasets.

Live data and big data can have ongoing cost related to reliable service provision.

_items.title: Hybrid approaches
_items.body:
Data management platforms take an active role in the control of any data they contain. On top of know what data exists, these platforms can search and manipulate the data itself.

For open data users, being able to search and manipulate the data without having to first download it makes reuse significantly easier.

For publishers however, there is a much greater challenge in structuring and formatting data such that the platform will accept it. Such challenges can be overcome if the publishing platform also becomes the means of access to the data for the publisher.

The Open Data Soft platform as used by data.sncf.com is a good example of such a platform.

_items.title: Comparison
_items.body:
Data catalogues provide:

  • Federated search across a wide domain
  • Mechanisms for discovery
  • Key metadata relating to licence and how up to date data is.

    • Data management platforms provide:

    • Authoritative sources for data
    • Increased quality
    • Ability to search and manipulate the data itself.

    Taking a hybrid approach provides the greatest potential for data reuse.
